course.title: Fishing Fundamentals: Ethics, Technique, and Modern Culture
course.targetAudience: Beginner to intermediate anglers; families and adult learners; ages 16+; non-commercial, safety-forward; U.S.-centric with local-law emphasis
course.designPhilosophy: Practical, outdoorsy, trustworthy. Clear diagrams for gear and rules; realistic story photos to make scenarios feel familiar and memorable.

learningScienceRationale.description: Pair concise explanations with diagrams and concrete scenes to increase recall.
Use structured comparisons and checklists so beginners can decide quickly without overload.
Use visual cues (icons, arrows, highlighted panels) to direct attention to the most important differences and legal rules.

layout.principle: Every element must earn its place

illustrationStyle.design: Clean vector infographics + realistic photo-based story images
illustrationStyle.shapes: Simple icons and panels for diagrams; natural scenes for photos
illustrationStyle.humanFigures: Real people in photos; no identifiable faces required (prefer turned-away or out-of-focus)

lessons.title: Bait, Laws, and the Rise of Sport Fishing
lessons.description: Compare live bait vs. lures, learn why local regulations matter, and understand how sport fishing evolved into a spectator culture.

visualizations.title: Live Bait vs. Lures: A Practical Comparison
visualizations.purpose: Help beginners choose between live bait and lures by comparing setup, effectiveness, ethics, and constraints.

panels.label: LIVE BAIT
characteristics: Pros: Natural scent/motion can trigger bites when fish are finicky
Pros: Often easier for beginners to get initial success
Cons: Requires bait care (keep alive/fresh) and storage
Cons: Higher chance of deep hooking if not monitored closely
Cons: Some waters restrict live bait to protect ecosystems
useCases: Targeting species that respond strongly to scent

panels.label: LURES
characteristics: Pros: Fast to deploy; easy to cover water and locate fish
Pros: Cleaner logistics (no live storage) and often more selective
Pros: Enables varied retrieves (jig, twitch, steady reel)
Cons: Learning curve to pick lure type and retrieve pattern
Cons: Can snag and require practice in structure-heavy areas

visualizations.bottomNote: Rule of thumb: Use live bait for natural presentation when fish are cautious; use lures to cover water and trigger reaction strikes. Always check whether live bait is allowed where you fish.

visualizations.title: Local Fishing Laws: The Quick Compliance Checklist
visualizations.purpose: Provide a simple, scannable set of legal checks anglers should follow before and during a trip.

distortions.name: LICENSE & PERMITS
distortions.definition: Ensure you have the correct license type (resident/nonresident), stamps, or endorsements required for the water and species.
distortions.example: Buy your license in advance and carry a digital/printed copy as required.

distortions.name: SEASONS & OPEN/CLOSED WATERS
distortions.definition: Some species or waters have seasonal closures or special rules (spawning protections, refuge zones).
distortions.example: Verify the season is open for your target species before you cast.

distortions.name: BAG LIMITS & SIZE LIMITS
distortions.definition: Know how many fish you can keep and any minimum/maximum size rules (including slot limits).
distortions.example: Measure fish immediately and release quickly if out of bounds.

distortions.name: GEAR & METHOD RESTRICTIONS
distortions.definition: Regulations may restrict hooks (barbless), bait (no live bait), number of rods, or use of nets/gigs.
distortions.example: Some trout waters allow only artificial lures with single barbless hooks.

distortions.name: INVASIVE SPECIES & BAIT TRANSPORT
distortions.definition: Moving live bait or water between locations can spread invasive species and disease.
distortions.example: Drain livewells and follow local bait-transport rules.

distortions.name: PROTECTED SPECIES & ETHICAL HANDLING
distortions.definition: Know which species must be released, and best practices to minimize harm (wet hands, quick photo, revive fish).
distortions.example: If you catch a protected species, release immediately and report if required.

visualizations.summaryNote: Regulations vary by state, water body, and species. Always verify the most current local rules from an official source before fishing.

visualizations.title: From Pastime to Spectator Sport: The Evolution of Sport Fishing
visualizations.purpose: Show how recreational fishing developed into organized tournaments and media-driven spectator events.

milestones.title: Recreation & Early Clubs
milestones.detail: Fishing grows as leisure activity; early clubs form shared norms and conservation ideas.

milestones.title: Gear Innovation & Wider Access
milestones.detail: Mass-produced rods, reels, and lines make fishing more accessible to the public.

milestones.title: Tournament Formats Appear
milestones.detail: Competitive events formalize rules, scoring, and weigh-ins; sponsorship begins.

milestones.title: TV, Internet, and Pro Circuits
milestones.detail: Media coverage expands audiences; pro anglers build brands and followings.

milestones.title: Live Coverage & Conservation Focus
milestones.detail: Live streams, GPS overlays, and catch-and-release best practices shape modern tournaments.

structure.footerNote: Modern sport fishing blends competition, storytelling, sponsorship, and conservation-minded handling.

visualizations.title: Early Morning Setup: Choosing Bait or Lure

scene.action: preparing tackle (choosing between bait container and lure tray)

natural colors, shallow depth of field

visualizations.title: The Smart Release: Ethical Handling in Real Life
visualizations.purpose: Reinforce the idea that legal compliance and ethical handling go together.

imageSpecs.brief: Realistic photo-style close scene: an angler with wet hands gently holding a fish just above the water surface for a quick release. No blood, no gore, no trophy pose; respectful handling.

subjects.pose: crouched, hands wet, supporting fish near water

accessibility.altText: A realistic close-up of wet hands gently supporting a fish at the water's surface during a careful catch-and-release.

natural daylight, shallow depth of field
